bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harry L. Freer, February 24, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests the key to the numbered buildings shown in a 1902 map of Columbia Barracks.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harry L. Freer, February 24, 1941
div1.opener:
February 24, 1941
Refer to File No. 314.7-1551
Mr. Harry L. Freer, Chief Clerk
Office of the Chief of Engineers, U. S. Army
War Department
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Freer:
div1.p:
I have received the maps referred to in your letter of February 20, the map of
Columbia Barracks made in 1907 and the key to the numbered buildings, also two copies of
a map of Columbia Barracks Reservation made in 1902 under the direction of Capt. Chauncey
B. Baker. I am indeed very grateful to you for sending them to me but I am most anxious
to have the key to the numbered buildings in this 1902 map which is marked "Columbia
Barracks G 10-02-2 Mil. Sta., Cuba with the figure 338 to the right of this designation.
Will you kindly send me two copies of the key to this map?

Permit me to explain my request. I have been investigating the historical
medical researches of Major Walter Reed and his colleagues who discovered the cause of
yellow fever. Their work was done in 1900-1901 at Columbia Barracks. The Cuban govern-
ment has purchased the land (shown in this 1902 map) just east of the Marianao railroad
and plans to erect a large and expensive memorial on the approximate site of the little
buildings numbered 113-120. I am most anxious to identify the various buildings in this
1902 map, especially those numbered 89 to 114 inclusive, plus 143. At the request of His
Excellency, Dr. Domingo Ramos, Minister of National Defense of the Cuban government I am
sending him shortly a documented statement as to the proper identity of these buildings
and of Camp Lazear. Since I must send this report within the next two weeks I would greatly
appreciate receiving the keys to the 1902 map at your earliest convenience.

Incidentally a model of the Columbia Barracks Post Hospital is at the Carlisle
Barracks (Pennsylvania) but has not been set up properly as they did not know how the
buildings were arranged. If you are willing to do so please send me an extra copy of the
1902 map with key to the buildings and I will send it to Col. John M. Willis, Acting
Commandant, Medical Field Service School, Carlisle Barracks, with whom I have had some
correspondence, or perhaps you would prefer to send it to him directly. I know they would
be glad to know the correct arrangement after all these forty years.

You say you were unable to find any maps of Camp Columbia as of 1900 or 1901;
could they have been listed as Columbia Barracks rather than Camp Columbia. The reason I
have been lead to believe that such a map existed is that I understand that a “small
property map” and “map of the Post” are mentioned (but not reproduced) in the Annual Report
of Chauncey B. Baker, Mayor Quartermaster U.S.V. Chief Quartermaster, Dept. of Cuba, report
dated June 30, 1901. This report appears in the Annual Report of the Commanding General
for 1901 (U. S. Adjutant General's office, Cuba Division). Unfortunately I have not been
able to get these reports. But apparently a map of the Post at Camp Columbia was made
prior to June 30, 1901.

Major Reed, in Nov. 1900, erected a special experimental camp, named Camp Lazear
on the San Jose Farm, Quemados, one mile from Camp Columbia. Here the final experiments
Mr. Harry L. Freer
- 2 -
February 24, 1941
to determine the cause of yellow fever were done. Have you any record of any
maps of Camp Lazear? I would certainly appreciate knowing this.

Will you permit me to enclose a copy of an address I recently made con-
cerning the above? It will explain my interest in all this and will, I believe,
interest you. I am indeed grateful for your generous help and will be very happy
to find, at last, the key identifying the buildings at Camp Columbia as of 1902
(or earlier).
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
